text: the Ouija board is probably the most
successful and recognizable object that
came out of the age of spiritualism in
this country uh it it it it's exactly
the kind of object that American
spiritualists were attracted to because
it had this do-it-yourself quality uh in
the 1850s 1860s American spiritualists
who believed ardently and what they were
doing had an ideal that eventually
talking to the dead would be as
effortless and as ordinary as dinnertime
conversation so they set themselves to
the task of figuring out how could this
be accomplished what method could we use
they experimented with uh trans
mediumship automatic writing there was a
little plank called the plette which is
French for a little plank that was used
uh you insert a pencil into it it was a
little triangular table on ball bearings
that was used for automatic writing and
eventually spiritualists hit on to
something they call the alphabet board
or the talking board this is what became
the Ouija board um the earliest image of
the Ouija board appeared in the New York
Herold Tribune in the year 1886 there
was an article about spiritualists in
Northern Ohio who were just entranced
with this thing that they called The
Talking board that was supposed to be
the easiest method yet for speaking to
the other side and the newspaper
featured a couple of drawings one of
them was just a little Max Matchbox siiz
drawing of the Ouija board and is the
spitting image of the board that we know
today they also showed a man and a woman
using uh the talking board balancing it
together on their knees which is
important because the the talking board
or the Ouija board was also a very
flirtatious experience for people in the
Victorian era it gave men and women an
excuse to sit KN to knee maybe even join
hands while they were Consulting this
magical board now the interesting thing
is the Ouija board was a homemade
invention uh it's it's it's it's the
earliest record of it probably is in
Ohio as seen in this 1886 newspaper
report um less than five years later
there were a group of novelty
manufacturers in the city of Baltimore
who seized upon the board and managed to
get a federal patent on it so they got
their patent and they called it the
Ouija board uh the name is a source of
mystery everybody has different stories
about where it came from nobody really
knows but the invention just the the
object just took off it spread across
the country people were enthralled with
it it became so popular that by
1922 um the artist Norman Rockwell
painted a satire of a man and woman
using the Ouija board which appeared on
the cover of the Saturday evening post
and if you look at Rockwell's satire you
see basically the same image uh that
appeared back in 1886 the man and woman
with their knees kind of bumping using
the Ouija board uh together it's it in
in Rockwell's painting it's it's sort of
weaving this little flirtatious spell
around them in
1966 the original Baltimore family uh
that manufactured the Ouija board sold
it to Parker Brothers and when Parker
Brothers marketed the board uh for the
first time the following year in 1967 it
actually outsold Monopoly that's how
popular the Ouija board was at that time
and the late 60s uh saw an occult
Revival sweeping through the nation the
the Woodstock generation was not only
open to Eastern religious ideas but they
were open to all kinds of occult ideas
that were coming out of the age of
spiritualism that were coming from um 19
century movements in this country one of
them was called the theosophy movement
which which had helped repop poize
occult Concepts in the late 19th century
so the late 60s saw an occult Revival
the Ouija board was at the ready and
young people embraced it Ouija circles
sprang up in dormitories um and
interestingly enough very often it was
women who were conducting the nightly
Ouija sessions which un owns to them was
a reenactment of spiritualism from the
the mid 19th
century company hasbo which owns Parker
Brothers and manufactures it uh does not
seem terribly interested to talk about
the board they continue to manufacture
it but last time I went on their website
they didn't post a history of the Ouija
board even though they have histories
for twister and The Game of Life and
other very story products that they sell
uh people are scared of Ouija they don't
want to attract boycotts from the
Christian right they don't want to
attract somebody who's going to commit
some kind of a crime and claim well the
Ouija board told me to do it that's part
of its history we never seem to have
been able to digest the Ouija board
because it is an object from the age of
spiritualism that has made it into
slumber parties and basements and toy
rooms all across the country and yet
there's this very frightening and weird
Urban mythology around the Ouija board
ask anyone and they have some strange
story of being a kid and using the Ouija
board and the lights flicked on and off
or they heard mysterious or ghostly
knocks at their door uh there are some
people in ult history who warned against
using the Ouija board who said this is a
dangerous door to the unconscious don't
approach this thing um so we like to
make fun of it we're sort of frightened
of it there's Nostalgia around it but
the fact is uh in some ways it reflects
the success of
spiritualism well the most common
explanation that you'll find is that
it's it's just a tool of of a suggestion
uh we are just using it to act out
Communications from our deepest
unconscious there are serious psychical
researchers who looked at the Ouija
board in the 1960s and that was the
conclusion they came up with h it's as
reasonable conclusion as any except when
you talk to people who use it and you
know you hear about the events they
describe they'll have none of it so it
it seems to be an object that's just
going to withhold its mysteries from
us
